pullrequest.title: Add battery class (redo of pull request #1782)

content.raw: We are building a drone (bebop first) simulator for internal use only. Its purpose is to help our development teams to test their algorithms in an environment where our firmware communicates with simulated captors and actuators. Gazebo is a key component of this environment.

pullrequest.title: Add battery class (redo of pull request #1782)

content.raw: Here's a question: `Update()` is going to internally call the UpdateFunction that will update the battery voltage based on a battery model (default or custom). If I'm writing a custom update function I believe I would like to know the elapsed delta time since the last update. According to the consumers, powerloads and dt, I'd be able to modify the voltage accordingly. Shouldn't we add `dt` as a parameter to the updateFunct and calculate `dt` internally inside `Update()`? @ocrave ?
content.html: Here's a question: Update() is going to internally call the UpdateFunction that will update the battery voltage based on a battery model (default or custom). If I'm writing a custom update function I believe I would like to know the elapsed delta time since the last update. According to the consumers, powerloads and dt, I'd be able to modify the voltage accordingly. Shouldn't we add dt as a parameter to the updateFunct and calculate dt internally inside Update()? @ocrave ?

pullrequest.title: Add battery class (redo of pull request #1782)

content.raw:
It's not possible to pass the time delta directly through the `Update()` function because the `Battery` has no knowledge of the `World` and simulation time. We have also left the process of updating the battery to the user, so they can update the battery at any time cycle.

The implementation of `UpdateFunction` can keep track of time themselves. This is done in the `LinearBatteryPlugin`.
content.html:
It's not possible to pass the time delta directly through the Update() function because the Battery has no knowledge of the World and simulation time. We have also left the process of updating the battery to the user, so they can update the battery at any time cycle.

The implementation of UpdateFunction can keep track of time themselves. This is done in the LinearBatteryPlugin.

pullrequest.title: Add battery class (redo of pull request #1782)

content.html:
This method is mistaken because because consumer IDs are not unique:

id1 = battery->AddConsumer();
id2 = battery->AddConsumer();
battery->RemoveConsumer(id1);
id3 = battery->AddConsumer();
assert(id3 != id2); // Fails

It should be rewritten like this:

uint32_t consumerId = 0;
auto iter = this->dataPtr->powerLoads.rbegin();
if (iter != this->dataPtr->powerLoads.rend())
  consumerId = iter->first + 1;
return consumerId;

pullrequest.title: Add battery class (redo of pull request #1782)

content.html:
I think you're updated version will also fail in this case:

id1 = battery->AddConsumer();
id2 = battery->AddConsumer();
battery->RemoveConsumer(id2); <---- Remove the last item 
id3 = battery->AddConsumer();
assert(id3 != id2);

We can use a separate counter variable that only increases.

pullrequest.title: Add battery class (redo of pull request #1782)

content.html:
But in that case, it is OK if it fails because the previous owner of id2 has released its ID. Although, I forgot to initialize the value:

uint32_t consumerId = 0;
auto iter = this->dataPtr->powerLoads.rbegin();
if (iter != this->dataPtr->powerLoads.rend())
  consumerId = iter->first + 1;
this->dataPtr->powerLoads[consumerId] = 0.0;
return consumerId;

A separate counter would be a little bit less efficient.

content.raw: Ahh okay. I assumed an id once generated would never be used again. I'll make the change.
content.html: Ahh okay. I assumed an id once generated would never be used again. I'll make the change.

  if (this->dataPtr->powerLoads.erase(_consumerId))

    return true;
  }

    return false;
  }
}

pullrequest.title: Add battery class (redo of pull request #1782)

content.raw:
This value seems to be overriding the voltage specified in the battery's SDF. I created a battery as follows and after a time step the voltage shows as 24+. Is this what we want?

~~~
...
        <battery name="linear_battery">
          <voltage>12.592</voltage>
        </battery>
      </link>
      <plugin name="battery" filename="libLinearBatteryPlugin.so">
        <link_name>body</link_name>
        <battery_name>linear_battery</battery_name>
        <open_circuit_voltage_constant_coef>25</open_circuit_voltage_constant_coef>
        <open_circuit_voltage_linear_coef>-3.1424</open_circuit_voltage_linear_coef>
        <initial_charge>1.1665</initial_charge>
        <capacity>1.2009</capacity>
        <resistance>0.061523</resistance>
        <smooth_current_tau>1.9499</smooth_current_tau>
      </plugin>
...
~~~
content.html:
This value seems to be overriding the voltage specified in the battery's SDF. I created a battery as follows and after a time step the voltage shows as 24+. Is this what we want?

...
        <battery name="linear_battery">
          <voltage>12.592</voltage>
        </battery>
      </link>
      <plugin name="battery" filename="libLinearBatteryPlugin.so">
        <link_name>body</link_name>
        <battery_name>linear_battery</battery_name>
        <open_circuit_voltage_constant_coef>25</open_circuit_voltage_constant_coef>
        <open_circuit_voltage_linear_coef>-3.1424</open_circuit_voltage_linear_coef>
        <initial_charge>1.1665</initial_charge>
        <capacity>1.2009</capacity>
        <resistance>0.061523</resistance>
        <smooth_current_tau>1.9499</smooth_current_tau>

...

pullrequest.title: Add battery class (redo of pull request #1782)

content.raw: I think `<open_circuit_voltage_constant_coef>` is suppose to indicate the maximum amount of voltage available with zero current. This is different from the `<battery>`'s voltage, which is the initial voltage of the battery. So, I think you've define a battery that is being charged.
content.html: I think <open_circuit_voltage_constant_coef> is suppose to indicate the maximum amount of voltage available with zero current. This is different from the <battery>'s voltage, which is the initial voltage of the battery. So, I think you've define a battery that is being charged.

content.raw: The linear battery plugin example is a slightly simpler version of our LiPo battery plugin. The `<open_circuit_voltage_constant_coef>` parameter is closely related to the initial voltage value. A change in one must always be accompanied by a change in the other.
content.html: The linear battery plugin example is a slightly simpler version of our LiPo battery plugin. The <open_circuit_voltage_constant_coef> parameter is closely related to the initial voltage value. A change in one must always be accompanied by a change in the other.

pullrequest.title: Add battery class (redo of pull request #1782)

content.raw: I guess my question is whether we need both parameters. Can we just use the battery's voltage here?
content.html: I guess my question is whether we need both parameters. Can we just use the battery's voltage here?

pullrequest.title: Add battery class (redo of pull request #1782)

content.raw:
The `<open_circuit_voltage_constant_coef>` is needed and may differ from the initial voltage value. If you prefer, you can use a bias in your XML:


```
#!xml
<open_circuit_voltage_constant_coef_bias>0.102</open_circuit_voltage_constant_coef_bias>
```

And then compute the linear coef like this in the `Load()` method:
```
#!c++
this->e0 = _sdf->Get<double>("open_circuit_voltage_constant_coef_bias") + this->battery->Voltage();
```
You should know that this is just a usage example. In reality, the equation that represents the open-circuit would require more terms.
content.html:
The <open_circuit_voltage_constant_coef> is needed and may differ from the initial voltage value. If you prefer, you can use a bias in your XML:

<open_circuit_voltage_constant_coef_bias>0.102</open_circuit_voltage_constant_coef_bias>

And then compute the linear coef like this in the Load() method:

this->e0 = _sdf->Get<double>("open_circuit_voltage_constant_coef_bias") + this->battery->Voltage();

You should know that this is just a usage example. In reality, the equation that represents the open-circuit would require more terms.

The battery seems to keep on being consumed even after the voltage is over, so the voltage goes negative. I also observed that sometimes after a few steps it might go back to positive, but eventually it settles at zero.
